body: @duytrung before the result summary, there should be output of all the failing tests, detailing what failed. Can you include that?
How can I do that, the Command Promp show only likely a hundred lines. How can I run and extract the results into a text file?

Oh, Okay. I have change the buffer and here is the results after reruning "iptest":


I'm not sure quite what we can do about this. We do run the tests on Windows ([Jenkins](https://jenkins.jupyter.org/)), where they are passing, give or take one or two sporadic failures. There is evidently something different about your system (e.g. it doesn't seem to be able to find python on PATH). None of the core developers routinely use Windows, so we don't have much interest in working out what is making the tests fail, as it's unlikely to be real bugs in IPython.

I ran the program as using the Command prompt and pointed it to "[python dir]\Scripts\ipython notebook"
@takluyver: how can I use Ipython in a more stable system? Do you mean that Linux or Mac?

I have updated packages to latest one, some packages I have downloaded from the website of Christoph Gohlke - http://www.lfd.uci.edu/~gohlke/pythonlibs/

If using IPython in Linux is more stable, I consider switch to Linux to master Python and related IPython for awhile.

I'm still python novice :-)

Thank you!

Windows is certainly a supported environment. If IPython is working for you, I would ignore the test failures: they're probably not important. If IPython is not working, please let us know about the problems you're seeing.

Most of the IPython developers use Linux or Mac computers, but we absolutely aim for it to work on Windows as well.

That one is an incompatibility with pygments 2. It should be fixed by the
next release of IPython. I'll look up the issue/PR numbers in the morning
if you're interested in the details.
Thanks, Thomas. It generates repeated stack traces in the terminal, but other than that I guess I can ignore it?
You may see some oddities with tab completion and/or syntax highlighting in the Qt console, but if you can live with that, it should be fine.
Closing as nothing much else we can do, and to keep the list of bug a bit shorter.
